cluster_relations.rel_desc: Various situations are described as contexts in which body language is used.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject represents a social or situational context within which the object behavior or process occurs or is expressed.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Body language is used by individuals specifically within professional settings.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject behavior or process takes place within, or is used in, the social or situational context represented by the object.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Body language is used by individuals within social situations.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject behavior or process takes place within, or is used in, the social or situational context represented by the object.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Function: establishing rapport and building connections

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Social interactions are contexts in which communication occurs.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject represents a social or situational context within which the object behavior or process occurs or is expressed.
remarks: Implicit relation; not literally stated but strongly suggested by framing.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject represents a social or situational context within which the object behavior or process occurs or is expressed.
args.justification: Both relations link a contextual situation (subject) to a communicative behavior/process (object) with identical semantics; they currently use two different canonical names ('is_context_for' vs 'provides_context_for') but share the same description. Normalizing them to a single predicate name 'provides_context_for' improves consistency of the schema while preserving directionality. Other fields (rel_cls, rel_cls_group) are already appropriate.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: The subject represents a social or situational context within which the object behavior or process occurs or is expressed.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations link a contextual situation (subject) to a communicative behavior/process (object) with identical semantics; they currently use two different canonical names ('is_context_for' vs 'provides_context_for') but share the same description. Normalizing them to a single predicate name 'provides_context_for' improves consistency of the schema while preserving directionality. Other fields (rel_cls, rel_cls_group) are already appropriate.
